text: The propensity score of a given post is an estimated probability that the post was "treated" based on all available covariates.

label: the covariates are the computed features summarized in Table 2 (except for the number of hyperlinks
column3: which relates directly to whether there is a Wikipedia link).`

text: The actual propensity score for each post is calculated by logistic regression and represents how likely a given post is to include a Wikipedia link (or a good Wikipedia link) based only on its features.
Posts that have features that are commonly found in Wikipedia-linked posts will therefore have high propensity scores.

label: we stratify [2] our datasets by propensity score (subdivide into many subsets) in order to emulate a randomized blocked trial using observational data.`

text: `Each stratum contains posts with a small range of propensity scores
label: so posts have similar features with each stratum
column3: which reduces the standardized bias (described by Rosenbaum and Rubin [45]).`

label: we also performed propensity score matching [2] and propensity score stratification with covariate overlap adjustment [8] and confirmed that these methods led to the same conclusions.`

text: Paradox of Re-use As noted above
label: a concern that has been raised within the Wikipedia community is the "paradox of re-use" ­ ie that the quality of Wikipedia's content and Wikipedia's editor base could decline over the long term through the external re-use of Wikipedia content (and that the re-using parties would then suffer as well) [49].`

text: `This concern leads to the question of whether Wikipedia needs to adapt its permissive licensing to survive
label: especially as its content is increasingly appearing on platforms more than a "click away" (eg voice assistants).`

text: `Given that we observed that Wikipedia-linking posts were receiving a great deal of attention and engagement on SO and Reddit
label: we were surprised that so little of this attention and engagement was returned to Wikipedia in the form of page views

text: We hypothesized that the paradox of re-use may be a factor.
`To understand exactly how SO and Reddit use content from Wikipedia
label: we performed a small-scale qualitative coding exercise.`

text: `Using the same approach to qualitative coding as the current events analysis
label: we classified whether each post matched the following definition of direct re-use: "Has text (quoted or summarized) from article."`

text: `Two authors conducted a calibration coding and achieved reasonable inter-rater agreement (Reddit: Cohen's  = 0.74
label: 90% agreement; SO: Cohen's  = 0.62; 90% agreement)
column3: and then one author coded 100 posts with Wikipedia links per site.`

text: `Our coding analysis revealed that 79% of Reddit posts had quoted or summarized text from the linked Wikipedia article
label: whereas this was true of 33% of SO posts.`

text: This result shows that many posts can be characterized by "direct re-use".
These early results help to expand our understanding of the nature of the "paradox of re-use" from McMahon et al [33].
McMahon et al found causal evidence for the paradox of reuse on Google ­ ie Knowledge Card assets in Google search results were capturing views that would have otherwise gone to Wikipedia.
`This indicates a "strong" version of the paradox of re-use
label: in which Google was capturing traffic that would have gone to Wikipedia.`

text: `Our (associative) results suggest that a "weak" form of the paradox may be occurring in Reddit and SO: the Wikipedia links on Reddit and SO posts might have generated new traffic for Wikipedia (rather than capturing existing traffic)
label: but the re-use of content directly in Reddit and SO may be mitigating this effect.`
it is critical to note that our results merely allow this as a possibility: future work should test this hypothesis directly

text: `Broadening Peer Production Research At a high level
label: the results of Study 1 demonstrate that there are important relationships between different peerproduction communities (with Reddit and SO themselves being peer production communities).`

text: `We see that when content creators on Reddit and SO leverage existing peerproduced content (ie Wikipedia) to create new content in their communities
label: some of the "value" transfers and the magnitude of that value is reflective of the re-used content's quality (in this case
Reddit and SO users can take advantage of the work already performed by the Wikipedia community to post higher value content in their communities with less effort.`

text: These relationships between peer production communities have important implications for research.
`Studies of some important variables such as content quality may want to consider external dependencies and implications
label: eg Wikipedia article quality matters well outside of Wikipedia
column3: adding importance to the body of work that studies Wikipedia quality and how to improve it [6

text: Coverage Biases and External Entities The work on Wikipedia content biases is another key research area in the Wikipedia literature that our results suggest should be examined with a broader lens.
`Wikipedia (and other UGC communities) have been shown to overfocus on some topics and under-focus on others
label: particularly
April 21­26
our results suggest that these biases may be having ripple effects around the web
the findings from Study 1 indicate that these biases mean that the TIL community on Reddit is working from a dataset that disadvantages women
column4: and topics outside of the cultural sphere of most English speakers.`

text: `Any posts about these Wikipediadisadvantaged topics that do appear on TIL are less likely to have a Wikipedia link (or high-quality link) available
label: and thus cannot get the benefits of that link.`

text: `There is a potential silver lining regarding coverage biases: while the number of edits contributed to Wikipedia from Reddit that we observed in Study 2 was quite small in the context of Wikipedia as a whole
label: it may be that this effect would be meaningful if applied to specific under-covered content areas.`
if more Wikipedia links were posted on a subreddit for rural issues
column3: the throughput of edits that is quite small for all of Wikipedia could make non-trivial improvements to coverage of some rural topics
column4: for which a small number of edits is a large relative increase in edits.`

text: One could also imagine the Wikipedia community (eg WikiProject leaders) working with the moderators of subreddits in under-covered areas on intentional "quality improvement projects" [53].
This might involve rallying these subreddits to encourage edits to relevant Wikipedia articles and to encourage members to become long-term editors.
`It would be interesting to compare the results of such an effort to our findings
label: which would provide an excellent baseline to determine if the effort was effective.`

text: `Implications for Reddit and Stack Overflow McMahon et al's work [33] indicated that financially supporting Wikipedia may be highly incentivized for search companies
label: and our work suggests that the same might be true for Reddit and SO (although to a lesser degree).`
our results suggest that by donating to Wikipedia
column3: entities like SO and Reddit can not only garner goodwill
column4: but also could feasibly see a return on investment.`

text: Our results indicate that one direction of research in this space that might be fruitful is identifying formal value propositions for external consumers of peer-produced content.
Our results also suggest that Reddit and SO design interventions could help increase the mutual value of Wikipedia-SO and Wikipedia-Reddit relationships.
